00060 using std::cerr;
00061 using std::endl;

00063 string escattr(string s);
00064 
00073 Str::Str(const string &n) : BaseType(n, dods_str_c), _buf("")
00074 {
00075 }
00076 
00077 Str::Str(const Str &copy_from) : BaseType(copy_from)
00078 {
00079     _buf = copy_from._buf;
00080 }
00081     
00082 BaseType *
00083 Str::ptr_duplicate()
00084 {
00085     return new Str(*this);
00086 }
00087 
00088 Str &
00089 Str::operator=(const Str &rhs)
00090 {
00091     if (this == &rhs)
00092     return *this;
00093 
00094     // Call BaseType::operator=.
00095     dynamic_cast<BaseType &>(*this) = rhs;
00096 
00097     _buf = rhs._buf;
00098 
00099     return *this;
00100 }
00101 
00102 unsigned int
00103 Str::length()
00104 {
00105     return _buf.length();
00106 }
00107 
00108 unsigned int
00109 Str::width()
00110 {
00111     return sizeof(string);
00112 }
00113 
00114 bool
00115 Str::serialize(const string &dataset, DDS &dds, XDR *sink, bool ce_eval)
00116 {
00117 
00118     DBG(cerr << "Entering (" << this->name() << " [" << this << "])" << endl);
00119 
00120     dds.timeout_on();
00121 
00122     if (!read_p())
00123       read(dataset);
00124 
00125     if (ce_eval && !dds.eval_selection(dataset))
00126     return true;
00127 
00128     dds.timeout_off();
00129 
00130     if (!xdr_str(sink, _buf))
00131     throw Error(
00132 "Network I/O Error. Could not send string data.\n\
00133 This may be due to a bug in DODS, on the server or a\n\
00134 problem with the network connection.");
00135 
00136     DBG(cerr << "Exiting: buf = " << _buf << endl);
00137 
00138     return true;
00139 }
00140 
00141 // deserialize the string on stdin and put the result in BUF.
00142 
00143 bool
00144 Str::deserialize(XDR *source, DDS *, bool)
00145 {
00146     if (xdr_str(source, _buf) != 1)
00147     throw Error(
00148 "Network I/O Error. Could not read string data. This may be due to a\n\
00149 bug in DODS or a problem with the network connection.");
00150 
00151     return false;
00152 }
00153 
00154 // Copy information in the object's internal buffers into the memory pointed
00155 // to by VAL. If *VAL is null, then allocate memory for the value (a string
00156 // in this case).
00157 //
00158 // NB: return the size of the thing val points to (sizeof val), not the
00159 // length of the string. Thus if there is an array of of strings (i.e., (char
00160 // *)s), then the return value of this mfunc can be used to advance to the
00161 // next char * in that array. This weirdness is needed because C programs
00162 // which will need to interface to libraries built using this toolkit will
00163 // not know about C++ strings and will need to use the C representation for
00164 // strings, but here in the toolkit I use the string class to cut down on
00165 // memory management problems.
00166 
00167 unsigned int
00168 Str::buf2val(void **val)
00169 {
00170     // Jose Garcia
00171     // The same comment justifying throwing an Error in val2buf applies here.
00172     if(!val)
00173     throw InternalErr(__FILE__, __LINE__, 
00174               "The incoming pointer does not contain any data.");
00175 
00176     if (*val)
00177     delete static_cast<string *>(*val);
00178 
00179     *val = new string(_buf);
00180 
00181     return sizeof(string);
00182 }
00183 
00184 // Copy data in VAL to _BUF.
00185 //
00186 // Returns the number of bytes needed for _BUF.
00187 
00188 unsigned int
00189 Str::val2buf(void *val, bool)
00190 {
00191     // Jose Garcia
00192     // This method is public therefore and I believe it has being designed
00193     // to be use by read which must be implemented on the surrogated library,
00194     // thus if the pointer val is NULL, is an Internal Error. 
00195     if (!val)
00196     throw InternalErr(__FILE__, __LINE__, "NULL pointer.");
00197 
00198     _buf = *(string *)val;
00199 
00200     return sizeof(string);
00201 }
00202 
00203 void 
00204 Str::print_val(ostream &os, string space, bool print_decl_p)
00205 {
00206     if (print_decl_p) {
00207     print_decl(os, space, false);
00208     os << " = \"" << escattr(_buf) << "\";" << endl;
00209     }
00210     else 
00211       os << '"' << escattr(_buf) << '"';
00212 }
00213 
00214 void 
00215 Str::print_val(FILE *out, string space, bool print_decl_p)
00216 {
00217     if (print_decl_p) {
00218     print_decl(out, space, false);
00219     fprintf( out, " = \"%s\";\n", escattr(_buf).c_str() ) ;
00220     }
00221     else 
00222       fprintf( out, "\"%s\"", escattr(_buf).c_str() ) ;
00223 }
00224 
00225 bool
00226 Str::ops(BaseType *b, int op, const string &dataset)
00227 {
00228     // Extract the Byte arg's value.
00229     if (!read_p() && !read(dataset)) {
00230       // Jose Garcia
00231       // Since the read method is virtual and implemented outside
00232       // libdap++ if we can not read the data that is the problem 
00233       // of the user or of whoever wrote the surrogate library
00234       // implemeting read therefore it is an internal error.
00235       throw InternalErr(__FILE__, __LINE__, "This value was not read!");
00236     }
00237 
00238     // Extract the second arg's value.
00239     if (!b->read_p() && !b->read(dataset)) {
00240       // Jose Garcia
00241       // Since the read method is virtual and implemented outside
00242       // libdap++ if we can not read the data that is the problem 
00243       // of the user or of whoever wrote the surrogate library
00244       // implemeting read therefore it is an internal error.
00245       throw InternalErr(__FILE__, __LINE__, "Argument value was not read!");
00246     }
00247 
00248     switch (b->type()) {
00249       case dods_str_c:
00250     return rops<string, string, StrCmp<string, string> >
00251         (_buf, dynamic_cast<Str *>(b)->_buf, op);
00252       case dods_url_c:
00253     return rops<string, string, StrCmp<string, string> >
00254         (_buf, dynamic_cast<Url *>(b)->_buf, op);
00255       default:
00256     return false;
00257     }
00258 }

00325 // Revision 1.43.4.3  2001/09/07 00:38:35  jimg
00326 // Sequence::deserialize(...) now reads all the sequence values at once.
00327 // Its call semantics are the same as the other classes' versions. Values
00328 // are stored in the Sequence object using a vector<BaseType *> for each
00329 // row (those are themselves held in a vector). Three new accessor methods
00330 // have been added to Sequence (row_value() and two versions of var_value()).
00331 // BaseType::deserialize(...) now always returns true. This matches with the
00332 // expectations of most client code (the seqeunce version returned false
00333 // when it was done reading, but all the calls for sequences must be changed
00334 // anyway). If an XDR error is found, deserialize throws InternalErr.
00335 //
00336 // Revision 1.44  2001/08/24 17:46:22  jimg

00338 //
00339 // Revision 1.43.4.2  2001/08/18 00:16:00  jimg

00341 //
00342 // Revision 1.43.4.1  2001/07/28 01:10:42  jimg
00343 // Some of the numeric type classes did not have copy ctors or operator=.
00344 // I added those where they were needed.
00345 // In every place where delete (or delete []) was called, I set the pointer
00346 // just deleted to zero. Thus if for some reason delete is called again
00347 // before new memory is allocated there won't be a mysterious crash. This is
00348 // just good form when using delete.
00349 // I added calls to www2id and id2www where appropriate. The DAP now handles
00350 // making sure that names are escaped and unescaped as needed. Connect is
00351 // set to handle CEs that contain names as they are in the dataset (see the
00352 // comments/Log there). Servers should not handle escaping or unescaping
00353 // characters on their own.
00354 //
00355 // Revision 1.43  2000/10/06 01:26:05  jimg
00356 // Changed the way serialize() calls read(). The status from read() is
00357 // returned by the Structure and Sequence serialize() methods; ignored by
00358 // all others. Any exceptions thrown by read() are caught and discarded.
00359 // serialize() returns false if read() throws an exception. This should
00360 // be fixed once all the servers build using the new read() definition.

00368 // Revision 1.41  2000/09/21 16:22:08  jimg
00369 // Merged changes from Jose Garcia that add exceptions to the software.
00370 // Many methods that returned error codes now throw exectptions. There are
00371 // two classes which are thrown by the software, Error and InternalErr.
00372 // InternalErr is used to report errors within the library or errors using
00373 // the library. Error is used to reprot all other errors. Since InternalErr
00374 // is a subclass of Error, programs need only to catch Error.

00511 // Revision 1.10  1995/03/04  14:34:50  jimg
00512 // Major modifications to the transmission and representation of values:
00513 // Added card() virtual function which is true for classes that
00514 // contain cardinal types (byte, int float, string).
00515 // Changed the representation of Str from the C rep to a C++
00516 // class represenation.
00517 // Chnaged read_val and store_val so that they take and return
00518 // types that are stored by the object (e.g., inthe case of Str
00519 // an URL, read_val returns a C++ String object).
00520 // Modified Array representations so that arrays of card()
00521 // objects are just that - no more storing strings, ... as
00522 // C would store them.
00523 // Arrays of non cardinal types are arrays of the DODS objects (e.g.,
00524 // an array of a structure is represented as an array of Structure
00525 // objects).
